slides.text:
# 01. Philosophical Influences 

 Filmmakers influence each other creatively; “creative influences” is what we love to talk about. It’s how we communicate, and it’s how we shape our artistic identities. 

 But we all function while influenced by a different force: Philosophers. 

 Philosophers shape our worldview in very subtle ways. When we talk about things like *justice*, *fairness*, *truth* or *ethics*, we're often echoing ideas rooted in the works of a long line of thinkers who’s name most people probably won’t even recognise. 

 From the way we frame ethical decisions to our assumptions about success, happiness, and human potential, to how we strategise and execute a project, philosophers are everywhere. 

 Their intellectual legacy forms an unseen foundation for our understanding of the world and ourselves. 

 And we are not alone. Some of the greatest minds of history acknowledged this fact…
Practical men, who believe themselves to be quite exempt from any intellectual influences, are usually the slaves of some *defunct economist*.
slides.reflectionText: Keynes may have a point, but where do these *defunct economists* get their ideas from?
slides.reference: Keynes, J. M. (1936). *The general theory of employment, interest, and money.* Palgrave Macmillan.

slides.text:
In fact, I'd go another step and say that we're usually slaves of some *philosophers*, defunct or not. 

 Some are not even philosophers, but figures of populism. 

 Very often, we're under the influence of something we intuitively feel to be true, but haven't thoroughly investigated what they meant in the context of their origins. 

 As we will soon see, feelings can be deceiving - especially ones without the backing of careful reasoning. 

 For example…

The professional intellectuals are, in effect, the field agents of the army whose head or commander in chief is the philosopher. 

 The professional intellectuals ... carry to the rest of the culture, the rest of society, the philosophical premises, the ideas which have been defined by the philosopher.
slides.reference: Ayn Rand Institute. (2015). James McConnell Interviews Ayn Rand About the New Intellectual. *In YouTube*. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IeaAC832gG4

slides.text:
Indeed, whether we're conscious or not, the philosophers or "generals" have already a deep seated influence on us. 

 You might be familiar with many of these sayings coming from them, whether you've read it from elsewhere, heard it from other people, or internalised it via the participation of internet culture. 

 For example...

slides.reflectionText:
Plato envisions a society where its rulers are governed by reason - ideally a *philosopher king* who pursues justice, truth, and wisdom. 

 He is critical of democracy, because he believe that it allowed unqualified individuals to make important decisions, who instead of ruling with reason plays to the whims of the masses, degenerating society into tyranny as they pursue self-interest and populism over justice and truth.

slides.reflectionText:
David Hume is known for his *empiricism*, arguing that all knowledge derives from sensory perception. He famously challenged the concept of causality, arguing that we cannot observe causality directly, but only the sequence of events and *infer* a "causal" connection - which brought humility into causal reasoning. 

 His philosophical insights contributed massively to the statistical procedures used in the scientific method, and underpins the field of *causal analysis* of this day which is routinely used in the quantitative fields.

slides.reflectionText:
Hegal's philosophy centres on the idea that we gain knowledge from a process of dialectical progression. His central idea is that when we face a novel situation, we first come up with a thesis and an antithesis, which then causes a bunch of contradictions. When we synthesise all these contradictions, we would have gain knowledge about something. 

 Hegal may not be as well known to most people. But I'm sure you've heard about the direct descendent of his theory – Marxism and its associated Historical Materialistic reinterpretation of the world.

slides.reflectionText:
According to Schopenhauer, the world is driven by a "will" which is a restless, insatiable desire that propels not only humans but also all natural phenomena. In human beings, the will manifests as desires and can never be satisfied, therefore leading to inevitable dissatisfaction. One must learn to transcend the will in order to find relief from the endless bipolar cycle of ecstasy and depression. 

 Schopenhauer also believes that artistic experiences such as music is a unique way to momentarily escape the will, and momentarily touch on a pure experience beyond the personal desire.

slides.reflectionText:
Ayn Rand's philosophy is known as Objectivism, essentially asserting that what we can perceive is reality, and therefore is knowable through reason. She asserts that each person is an end in themselves. Therefore, *rational self-interest* is the highest moral purpose. 

 In her view, emotions and faith are unreliable guides to truth; only objective reality and rational thought can provide an accurate understanding of the world.

slides.text:
At this point, you might say... "Fascist Mike! What kind of Hitler joke is this!" 

 ... Now, now. Before you start sharpening that pitchfork, consider this... 

 **Imagine for a moment** that you were a citizen in Germany in the years between the two World Wars... 

 ... Having just endured the deep humiliation of defeat and forced into the crushing terms of the Treaty of Versailles 

 ... having watched your country be looted for over a decade while the allied powers feast on the blood of your family and neighbours...

 ... while you break your back and grind your hands to the bone and the children of your people still starve and freeze to death on the streets, 

 ... those who didn't were devoured by the machine which produces steel used to make lipsticks that the allied masters now apply make up before going to a fancy dinner. 

 ... All for a war you did not start and your family did not fight. But nobody cared and there was nothing you could do...

Then, one day, amidst the grief and agony came a whisper. Of a rumour, of one who they say carries the promise of restoring pride, dignity, and a path out of the darkness of despair. 

 You look around you. An election is coming, and your peers are excited. That man there with just 1 arm, he talk with hope and excitement and he is more alive than he has ever been since he lost his son in the war. 

 Some years later, your country is now winning wars. It dealt devastating blows to the powers that once enslaved you. 

 Ask yourself this. could you really resist the allure of Hitler at that time? Could you truly say that you won't be swayed by him? 

 Some years down the line, your situation drastically improved. You now eat better, sleep better, and your children went to not factories but school. Your leader demonstrated his genius military leadership and one after another you conquered the people who oppressed you for decades. You see some people disappearing on the streets, but you didn't know or like them anyway. 

 Are you really going to oppose him? Are you really going to stick your neck out for the people who continued to have stake throughout the interwar period while you lost an arm in a steel mill accident? Are you really going to question the visionary leader who worked tirelessly for over 25 years to make this all happen, when the alternative was utter anguish and ruination?

I for one, find these questions impossible to answer... ... Not without a shiny, thick set of philosophical armour. An independent mind of reason, perception, and most importantly, moral judgement. We tend to think that these people exist outside of ourselves. They do not. The archetypal influences they represent are all within us. And we have hopefully seen, they are within us whether we're conscious of them or not. "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." - Johann Wolfgang von Goethe When our minds are taken over by an idea, they stay with us. It'd be useful to find out what generals we're fighting for, don’t you think?
